unnormalised: Someone asked me about emergency medical situations in India, and what to do. It reminded me of a crazy night a few years back. My cousin, Rohan, was visiting from the US. We were having a family dinner when suddenly, around 9:30 PM, his face went pale and he clutched his chest.

normalised: He's usually healthy, so we were all panicked. He was saying it felt like an "elephant sitting on my chest." My aunt immediately started reciting Hanuman Chalisa, while I called one zero two for an ambulance. Trying to keep calm, I remembered some basic first aid. I asked him if he had any allergies or medical conditions. Turns out, he's allergic to shellfish, and we had a prawn dish that evening. He probably didn't realize it. His breathing became labored, and his face started swelling.

unnormalised: The ambulance arrived in what felt like forever, maybe 25 mins, thankfully quite prompt for Delhi traffic on a Saturday night! The EMTs quickly assessed Rohan. They checked his vitals (BP was 90/60), and administered an epinephrine injection - an EpiPen, as Rohan called it. The hospital was thankfully close by, Max Hospital, Saket, just a 15 min drive with sirens blaring. They started him on oxygen in the ambulance itself.
normalised: The ambulance arrived in what felt like forever, maybe twenty five minutes, thankfully quite prompt for Delhi traffic on a Saturday night! The E-M-T-s quickly assessed Rohan. They checked his vitals (B-P was ninety slash sixty), and administered an epinephrine injection - an EpiPen, as Rohan called it. The hospital was thankfully close by, Max Hospital, Saket, just a fifteen minute drive with sirens blaring. They started him on oxygen in the ambulance itself.

unnormalised: At Max, the emergency room staff were ready and waiting. They quickly took him in and started administering more medication, including antihistamines and corticosteroids. Dr. Sharma, the attending physician, explained he was experiencing anaphylactic shock. He was kept under observation in the ICU overnight. His bills amounted to approximately Rs. 35000.
normalised: At Max, the emergency room staff were ready and waiting. They quickly took him in and started administering more medication, including antihistamines and corticosteroids. Doctor Sharma, the attending physician, explained he was experiencing anaphylactic shock. He was kept under observation in the I-C-U overnight. His bills amounted to approximately rupees thirty five thousand.

unnormalised: Thankfully, Rohan made a full recovery. The whole experience was a wake-up call. We learned the importance of knowing about allergies, having emergency contacts readily available, and knowing the closest hospitals. Most importantly, calling for an ambulance (102) ASAP can truly save a life. And if you suspect anaphylaxis, an EpiPen (if available) can be a game-changer, but always follow up with proper medical treatment. Always best to be prepared and to know a few basic first aid steps.
